awd_titl_txt: Direct Numerical Simulation and Analysis of Turbulent Pipe Flow at High Reynolds Numbers
awd_abstract_narration:
For nearly four decades, the National Science Foundation (NSF) has played a leadership role in provisioning advanced cyberinfrastructure capabilities for the Nation's Science and Engineering (S&E) researchers. An important component in this investment is the leadership-class computing program that provides computational and data analytics capabilities at the largest scale to inspire transformative S&E discoveries that would not be possible otherwise. NSF's current leadership-class computing investment supports Frontera, the largest High-Performance Computing (HPC) system on a US academic campus. The Frontera system is deployed and operated by the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) at the University of Texas (UT) at Austin. This travel grant will support the participation of researchers who have been awarded a computer time allocation on the Frontera system at a future Principal Investigator (PI) meeting organized by TACC. The award will also support travel for technical coordination between researchers and the Frontera project to ensure optimal and effective utilization of the Frontera system.

The goal of the PI meeting is to allow Frontera research users, as well as their students, to share scientific results, exchange practical lessons-learned, and present their overall experience from using the Frontera system. In addition to research presentations, the meeting will have ample time, as well as facilitated sessions, to promote increased interaction between Frontera research users and project staff. The outcome of the PI meeting will not only enable the Frontera project to better understand and serve the scientific research community, but also build a community to better represent the unique needs of S&E research that require access to NSF leadership computing facilities. To facilitate deeper coordination beyond the PI meeting, this award will also provide travel support to enable technical coordination between the research user teams and the Frontera project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Title: Direct numerical simulation and analysis of turbulent pipe flow at high Reynolds numbers
Award Number: 2031650
Principal Investigator: Fazle Hussain
Institution: Texas Tech University

 The main outcome of this award was to achieve direct numerical simulation (DNS) of high Reynolds number turbulent pipe flow. High Reynolds numbers turbulent flows have numerous applications, hence we aimed to enhance our understanding of turbulence physics and contribute to the development of more accurate turbulence models for industrial applications. In addition, pipe flow is enshrouded in a number of controversies, some of which we also hope to address and resolve.

Intellectual Merit

High Reynolds number turbulent flows have numerous applications, hence we aimed to enhance our understanding of turbulence physics and contribute to the development of more accurate turbulence models. We have performed high-fidelity DNS up to a Reynolds number of 5,200 using the open-source pseudo-spectral code OPENPIPEFLOW. This is the highest Reynolds number pipe flow simulation so far, and we are extending it to much higher Reynolds numbers (currently Re_tau is 10,000). Our particular focus has been to provide accurate data by using a high-order numerical method, large domains, and sufficient integration time with quantified uncertainty. We have gathered a wealth of statistical data with uncertainties from our simulations, including mean velocity, Reynolds stress, pressure and its fluctuations, and energy spectra (available online at https://dataverse.tdl.org/dataverse/turbpipe).

Extensive comparisons between our new pipe data and other simulation and experimental data have been made, and differences between the various datasets were identified, and we have come up with some explanations for some of these differences. This work resulted in a major paper in a top journal and three high level conference presentations, and has been enthusiastically received and appreciated by leading experts as evidenced by recent citations in top journals and top conference presentations. Additional papers are under preparation.

Paper:

1. Direct numerical simulations of turbulent pipe flow up to Re_tau=5200, J Yao, S Rezaeiravesh, P Schlatter, F Hussain, Journal of Fluid Mechanics 956, A18, 2023.

Presentations:

1. Spectral data-driven analysis of high Reynolds-number turbulent pipe flows, D Massaro, J Yao, S Rezaeiravesh, F Hussain, P Schlatter, Bulletin of the American Physical Society, 2023.

2. Direct numerical simulation of turbulent pipe flow at Re_tau= 10,000, P Schlatter, J Yao, D Massaro, S Rezaeiravesh, F Hussain, Bulletin of the American Physical Society, 2023.

3. Estimating uncertainty of low-and high-order turbulence statistics in wall turbulence, S Rezaeiravesh, D Xavier, R Vinuesa, J Yao, F Hussain, P Schlatter, 12th International Symposium on Turbulence and Shear Flow Phenomena, TSFP, 2022. 

Broader Impact

This work not only complements both the existing high-Re simulations of turbulent boundary layer and channel flows, but also is critical for addressing some important issues/controversies revealed in recent high-Re turbulent pipe experiments. Apart from its fundamental importance as a paradigm flow with translational and rotational symmetries, pipe flow is ubiquitous in a variety of situations including city water supply, gas and oil pipelines, etc. The data we have made freely available is a valuable resource for the scientific community, facilitating further research and experimentation in the field of turbulent pipe flow physics and fluid dynamics in general and various technological devices involving heat and mass transfer.

Modified by: Fazle Hussain
